Author: 246tnt
Content: Huh ... so as part of testing I wanted to remove the `DualGate` layer from the standar cells to make the transistors 3v3 instead of 5V. Yes, they're gate would be longer than needed because I'm not resizing them, just changing the oxide thickness, hoping for them to get faster basically.

Author: 246tnt
Content: First theory is of course, thinner oxide means more gate capacitance and whatever gain we have from the thinner oxide forming better channel gets overwhelmed by the higher gate capacitance.

Author: 246tnt
Content: I could also have screwed up my simulation somewhere ...

Author: tholin
Content: I'd say its because the gate lengths are still the same

Author: 246tnt
Content: Well yeah, I know it's because their length is the same, but through what effect.

Author: 246tnt
Content: At 3.3V Vg and Vds, Ids is higher for 3v3 one (as expected) so it's better at passing current. (same W/L)

Author: 246tnt
Content: Although looking at the curve, it's really not _that_ much better.

Author: bailey8889
Content: @tnt For a given gate size, wouldn't lower voltages mean slower circuits?

Author: 246tnt
Content: @bailey I'm changing the transistor type, but both get powered using 3v3 .

Author: 246tnt
Content: Of course if I'm powering the 5V with 5V they go faster üòÅ
